physDesc.p: The letter consists of two sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of the first and one side of the second. At the top of the back side is “R.A.” in the left corner and the date in the right. There appears to be a watermark on the paper that reads “Berkshire Linen,” visible upside down on the top of the first page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I hope you will approve of what I have done with Brown. It consists chiefly in having given him a delightful jolt.

As your book is not yet out, and as I have waited some two months since you asked me to take the sheets away from him, I decided that I had better take the sheets away from him at once. So I telephoned him to that effect. He was extremely angry, and told me he would not relinquish them; whereupon I waxed wroth in my turn and told him that if they were not forthcoming the next day, I should send a lawyer to get them. If he refused to give them to the lawyer, I should go to court. We had a long and heated discussion, in which I made him realize pretty firmly that my reputation for honesty was unassailable, whereas his was not; and that if he went to law with me on the subject, it would ruin his professional reputation completely. I also told him that I should conduct the lawsuit myself, so that he need not think that his only adversary was some one living in England.

I then hung up the receiver and awaited developments. They came a few hours later, in the shape of another telephone message from Mr. Brown, containing the following amazing proposition: namely, that he would pay you royalties for 500 copies in advance of publication!

Your contract calls for 10% of royalties of the gross receipts, up to the first thousand copies sold. He is going to retail the book at 60¢ a copy, which would make $30.00 your royalties for 500 copies. This he agrees to pay on or before the 15th of the present month.

This proposition was made to me to induce me to allow him to continue the publication of the book. I accepted it, which I hope you will consider was the right thing to do; for it seemed to me that the chances of your selling 500 copies of this book anywhere else within a reasonable length of time – particularly as we have no other publisher over here (and it is doubtful if you can get one) – are extremely slim. Also, you will easily perceive that Brown would want to reimburse himself as quick as possible for the $30.00 paid you. It will, therefore, be very clearly to his advantage to push the sale of your book.

I do not in the least fear his not paying the money, as I and my lawyer and my lawsuit are still ready to jump upon him if he does not come up to time. And if that suggestion has frightened him so much once as to have him make you this offer, I imagine that its potency will not evaporate in two weeks.

I think then I should leave him about a little over six months to sell his 500 copies in, and then I think we can properly ask him for a statement of sales up to date, in case he owes you farther[sic] royalties. I trust you will think I have done well. Personally, this is far beyond my wildest hopes. Of course, it is true that you have lost the copyright on a certain number of the poems in this volume. But Mr. Brown intends to copyright the book just the same, as he says no human being will ever go through search the English edition to see which poems are really copyrighted and which are not, so that, for all practical purposes, your claims are protected.

I have no faith, nor any improvement to hope for, in Brown. I think he has proved himself not only unbusinesslike, but untrustworthy, and I certainly should not recommend his publishing any other books to anybody. And But if at any future time you want to, I imagine you can buy the copyright from him without much difficulty. And I think, further, than that he will be out of business before long. At the rate he is going, and in that case would be quite willing to part with the copyright.
Hilda writes me that you have gone to Devonshire. Lovely country! I once passed a whole summer there.
We expect to get the “Imagist Anthology 1916” out in the month middle of April. I will, of course, send you copies as soon as they come.

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: Here is your contract, signed. Brown says he has already sent you one, but I doubted it so much that I made him give me another.

div.note: Aldington ultimately publishes his book, Images, Old and New (1916), with Edmund R. Brown's press, Four Seas.
